customer_addr:
3101 SE Ferry Slip Rd
Newport, OR 97365

citations.narrative:
The back storage area, in close proximity to hay and bedding storage, contains metal, wood and plastic material piled up
haphazardly so that there is no way to visualize underneath. This may affect animal welfare due to the pile of debris
making it an optimal condition for attracting vermin that could be a health risk to the animals. The piled material should be
placed in designated areas so that the storage area can be visualized and cleaned as necessary to protect the health of
the animals. Correct before next re-license inspection.

There are three areas with sharp-edged pieces of welded metal within an 8-inch by 36-inch open gap between the top
and second rail of sectioned fencing where the emu has head and neck access. The effect to animal welfare is due to a
risk of injury to the emu's head and neck if she puts her head through the gap in the fencing next to the sharp metal. The
enclosure must be free of sharp edges which could be injurious to birds. Correct before next re-license inspection.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 23, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires on September 30, 2024.
n

narrative:
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The back storage area, in close proximity to hay and bedding storage, contains metal, wood and plastic material piled up 
haphazardly so that there is no way to visualize underneath. This may affect animal welfare due to the pile of debris 
making it an optimal condition for attracting vermin that could be a health risk to the animals. The piled material should be 
placed in designated areas so that the storage area can be visualized and cleaned as necessary to protect the health of 
the animals. Correct before next re-license inspection. 
3.153(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
There are three areas with sharp-edged pieces of welded metal within an 8-inch by 36-inch open gap between the top 
and second rail of sectioned fencing where the emu has head and neck access. The effect to animal welfare is due to a 
risk of injury to the emu's head and neck if she puts her head through the gap in the fencing next to the sharp metal. The 
enclosure must be free of sharp edges which could be injurious to birds. Correct before next re-license inspection. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 23, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires on September 30, 2024. 
 
 n
